question: Morning Joe. Beautiful day.
answer: You work here?

question: Yes, I do.
answer: What do you do?

question: I'm an Evolutionary Biologist. What do you do?
answer: Nothing. I'm in third grade. What's a revolutionary what ch'a ma' callit?

question: Evolutionary Biologist. I study how life on earth evolved over millions of years.
answer: Way cool. Then you know where the dinosaurs are.

question: You will be after tomorrow night. What the... ? No, it can't be. Damn. Beauregard! You scared me half to death.
answer: I'm sorry, sir. You okay?

question: Someone broke into this room.
answer: Anything missin'?

question: Doesn't look like it. We're damned lucky. This statue is priceless. Mbwun. A South American warrior deity. He carries a powerful curse. Every member of the expedition that found this statue, died.
answer: Looks like the curse is still at work.

question: The claws are sharp... I must have cut myself. Better move these crates to the secure storage area where they'll be safe.
answer: Don't know if it'll do any good, Mr. Cuthbert.

question: Why not?
answer: No one broke into this room, sir. Someone broke out. That lock was torn off from the inside.

question: Third from the end! Right shoulder. Aleut, provenance unknown. If I spent half the time on my Fractal Evolution thesis that I spend on this fly rod, I'd have my PhD.
answer: But at what a price. I have the species identification on these teeth. We can extract DNA and start running tests on the extrapolator program. Call Dr. Frock. He wanted a demonstration.

question: Margo, you haven't heard?
answer: What?

question: Frock's been fired.
answer: That's impossible.

question: I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings, but you know me. Telegraph. Telephone. Tell Kawakita. I got the definitive word from Cuthbert's secretary. This is Dr. Frock's last week.
answer: Is it true? Greg said you'd been fired.

question: Is it true? Greg said you'd been fired.
answer: Yes. Bit of a shock. But as Cuthbert so tactfully put it, the museum needs new blood. And since I've been here since the Mesozoic Era --

question: I don't believe it.
answer: Now Margo, don't overreact. Cuthbert has to cut costs somehow. My leaving makes perfect sense. This isn't exactly early retirement. I've overstayed the party a bit.

question: We can't do without you. You're one of the foremost authorities on primitive pharmacology. You're practically an institution around here.
answer: That, apparently, is the problem. I'm yesterday's news. Who needs a Curator of Plant Biology in a museum with one exhibit on plants? Monsters and dinosaurs, cannibals and shamans are the new currency of the realm.

question: "Phyletic Transformation and the Tertiary Fern Spike" is not going anywhere. I'll talk to Cuthbert and put a stop to this right now.
answer: Please. Don't humiliate me further.

question: Let me help. I can take care of everything.
answer: No, Margo. This is one problem you can't solve. You have to stay out of it. The fact is, I want to retire.

question: How can you say that? You know it's not true.
answer: Yes it is. I'm tired and I'm no longer needed --

question: My work on fossil intermediates would be crippled without you.
answer: With all due respect, dear, that's bull. You dance rings around me with your new technology. You've left me in the dust.

question: Your work is highly relevant. What about your display on Primitive Pharmacology? Cuthbert told me himself he was going to feature it prominently in the Superstition Exhibit.
answer: Healing plant use among the Ki tribe of Bechuanaland has been cancelled to make room for Tibetan Erotic Art. Come on. I'll walk you back to the elevator.

question: I'm not giving up.
answer: You must. This isn't a death sentence. Greg has promised to teach me fly fishing. I'll garden. I'll write.

question: You are this museum. It won't be the same without you.
answer: Everyone needs a change of scenery. I've been rolling down these halls for forty-odd years. That's quite enough. I'll see you at lunch.

question: Mrs. Beasley, it's almost time to go and we still haven't seen the dinosaurs!
answer: This room sucks.

question: She's never going to take us to see the dinosaurs. That lady said they were on the fourth floor.
answer: Let's ditch and find them ourselves. Look at this. A Komodo dragon.

question: Check out this one. It can walk up walls.
answer: We're not supposed to go back there.

question: Chicken. This is a great short cut.
answer: I don't want to go this way.

question: Don't be a wuss. Come on. Hey, there's a secret staircase back here. Cool.
answer: Henry, come back! Henry! Henry! Henry? Henry! Come up! Please! Henry? Where are you? Henry? Henry! Henry! It smells awful. Answer me! Are you all right?

question: Quiet!
answer: What is it?

question: Could you please take me to the officer in charge?
answer: Don't touch anything until the S.O.C. has finished with those stairs. Keep everyone clear of the perimeter. I don't want any contamination. There's an incredible amount of blood evidence down here. We need more light. Where's the photographer? Tell him to quit eating donuts, I need him. Who are you? The undertaker?

question: Special Agent Pendergast. FBI.
answer: Vince D'Agosta. Am I out?

question: Not at all. I think we may be working on the same case. If so, I could use your help. The body?
answer: What's left of it.

question: Mind if I have a look?
answer: We need light in here, stat.

question: Where's the head?
answer: Careful. That mess on the ground is brains.

question: Whose footprints?
answer: Night watchman who found the body. Sweet old man. Been tossing his cookies for over an hour. Not a likely suspect. Woof.

question: Get a life.
answer: An original Roger Tory Peterson of a Red-Breasted Merganser. Amazing. I have a copy of this in my office at home.

question: Can't really focus on birds at the moment, Pendergast. I'm tryin' to keep my breakfast down.
answer: In this violent world, I believe the only way to stay sane is to take time to notice beautiful things.

question: I drink. After hours of course. On duty, I smoke. Do you mind?
answer: Not at all. I enjoy the smell of a good cigar.

question: Then you won't like this one. It's a piece of shit.
answer: Lieutenant --

question: Call me Vince.
answer: Did you read about a boat that washed up outside of New Orleans about four months ago? Twelve bodies on board.

question: Who didn't? Big news. Out of Brazil, wasn't it?
answer: Yes. That's my case. Now it's yours. All the corpses were badly mutilated in a very particular way. Decapitated. Brains extracted. Limbs torn to shreds. It looked like the work of a large animal, but there was no sign of an animal on board.

question: So the method of death is the only connection?
answer: No. There's more. There were crates from this museum in the hold of the boat.

question: No.
answer: If you don't mind, this could be important.

question: You're kidding.
answer: Unfortunately, no.

question: We were lost and trying to find a short cut to the dino--
answer: We were just lost, okay? And we went down this curvy staircase. At the bottom was a big shadow.

question: Big as a house.
answer: Not that big.

question: Well almost. Depends which house. It smelled like old hamburger, and it made this weird noise. And it snuffled the ground like a dog.
answer: Like this.

question: It had a long tongue, teeth this big and yellow eyes.
answer: They were green eyes and they were slit like a lizard's.

question: They were yellow!
answer: You're color blind.

question: I've got to admit, that was a damn sight better than "the dog ate my homework".
answer: How do you explain the part about Beauregard?

question: They heard the victim's name and wove him into their story. Nice touch.
answer: I believed them.

question: You think what we've got here is a monster as big as a house that smells... like hamburger?
answer: No. I think what we've got here is a psychotic killer wielding some kind of unusual weapon... who wants us to believe he's a monster.

question: Shall we get down to it, then? This is Dr. Matilda Ziewzic, assisted by Dr. Frederick Gross. It's Oct. 28, six fifteen p.m. We are joined by Lieutenant Vincent D'Agosta of the NYPD, Special Agent Pendergast of the FBI and a police photographer. Let's see what we've got. Caucasian male. Age about 27. Blond. Height well I can't give a height because Mr. Beauregard has been decapitated. The state of the body is such that other identifying marks are out of the question. There are numerous lacerations proceeding from the left anterior pectoral downwards through the sternum and terminating in the abdomen. This is a massive wound, two feet long and a foot wide. The head has suffered severe trauma and the occipital portion of the calavarium has been crushed and removed. It almost looks like... What are we talking about here?
answer: Someone who makes the Hacksaw Murderer look like Mother Teresa.

question: Right. The entire brain appears to have been extracted. May I see it, please? Curious. There's something missing.
answer: The thalamus and the hypothalamus, perhaps?

question: What happened to them?
answer: If you don't mind a suggestion, you might try a saliva test.

question: Saliva test? You mean, you think someone ate part of the brain?
answer: Correct.

question: Long fingernails? Scratches? Sweet Jesus. I don't like animals. Never have. Dog bit me when I was little. After that I gave up on pets. Animals are irrational. Give me a psychotic killer any day. If there's one thing that makes me queasy it's being part of a food chain. My first case as a rookie, two brothers climbed a fence at the zoo. It was late August. Over ninety. The polar bear was inside his cave. Kids didn't know he was in there. All they saw was the pool. They got to swimming and splashing. The noise woke up the bear. By the time I arrived, both little boys were in pieces. The bear was dragging one kid around by the foot. I can still hear the mother screaming --
answer: This isn't an animal, Vince. I've been on this case four months, remember? I've learned a few things.

question: You've been holding out on me Pendergast. You have a suspect capable of this?
answer: Let me tell you about it, Vince. Excuse me. Has Dr. Green left?

question: Dr. Green?
answer: You have a warrant to look at that?

question: Special Agent Pendergast. FBI. Forgive me. I guess I was snooping. What is this?
answer: An invention of mine. It's a computer program designed to describe the characteristics of a given species from a reading of its DNA. I call it the Genetic Sequence Extrapolator.

question: How does it work?
answer: With a DNA analysis from a fossil you can use this program to tell the species and sex of the animal, whether it was nocturnal, what it ate, how it hunted, how big it was... You aren't here for a lesson in DNA.

question: No. I came to talk about Dr. John Whittlesley.
answer: Somehow, when all this happened... I knew it would come back to John. Is he really dead?

question: Maybe not.
answer: If he were alive he'd have contacted me.

question: You have time to talk? Dr. Whittlesley was last seen in Belem, Venezuela a week after the rest of his expedition disappeared. A taxi driver drove him to the harbor where he boarded a cargo boat. That boat washed up in my district. Everyone on board was killed.
answer: And John?

question: Disappeared. His body wasn't among the victims.
answer: I don't understand.

question: The people killed were mauled and their brains were eaten. Just like Beauregard. One part of the brain was extracted with surgical precision. The hypothalamus and thalamus to be exact.
answer: John couldn't have anything to do with a horrible thing like that. He was a fine man despite his problems --

question: You loved him.
answer: Yes. Once. We met at Columbia. John held the Cadwalader Chair in Statistical Paleontology when I was a grad student there.

question: You were going to be married.
answer: How did you know that?

question: I ran an internet search on Dr. Whittlesley. Got a list of his scholarly articles and the engagement announcement in the Times. I also found a record of your restraining order.
answer: That was two years ago. John was still in love with me. He wouldn't leave me alone.

question: You were afraid of him, weren't you?
answer: He was afraid of himself. He tried suicide once. He was ill. Manic depressive. He had wild emotional highs and lows. Not a happy affliction for a scientist. He'd been revered in our community. By the end he was a joke.

question: Tell me about the last expedition. What was he looking for?
answer: A legendary monster called Mbwun.

question: A monster?
answer: Yes. He developed his own theory that he called the Calisto Effect. It held that evolution wasn't always gradual or driven by natural selection. The environment would sometimes cause sudden and grotesque changes which could result in a "monster species". It made no sense. But he felt he had evidence that Mbwun was such a monster, living in isolation on the tepui for thousands of years.

question: What happened?
answer: No one knows. The Kothoga who live on the tepui are cannibals. No. I'm all right. I won't let this affect me anymore. John wouldn't get help. His ego endangered the lives of others. His theory came first.

question: What if Whittlesley arrived on the tepui and no monster was there? Was he desperate enough to create one?
answer: I don't understand.

question: Something came up in autopsy tonight. Imbedded in Beauregard's body we found a claw.
answer: My God. Then it was an animal.

question: I don't think so. I think we were meant to think it was Mbwun. Did Whittlesley's monster have claws?
answer: I don't know. He sent back a statue that's supposed to be an exact representation. But I've never seen it. It's in the exhibit.

question: Would you mind showing it to me? Where would we find it?
answer: I'm not sure. We should split up. You take that hall and I'll take this one.

question: All right. I'm as macho as you are. Perhaps.
answer: Mr. Pendergast! I found it. Pendergast! Over here -- What the... Pendergast? Who's there?

question: Dr. Green! Dr. Green! What happened?
answer: I don't know.

question: I heard you calling and I ran after you, but you kept disappearing and I couldn't keep up.
answer: You were behind me? Running after me? It's okay, I'm all right. I remember now... It was an animal. Something large! I could smell it. It was hunting me. I saw two green eyes in the dark.

question: Where did you see it?
answer: Behind me. Over there. That's not what I saw.

question: All right. If you're positive.
answer: I can't think straight at the moment. I know how crazy this seems. Please, Mr. Pendergast, I need some fresh air. Could you get me out of here?

question: Dr. Green...
answer: I didn't imagine it. I know what I saw. Are you sure there are enough men in there?

question: They're all heavily armed.
answer: All right. This is hard for me. I'm a scientist. I like order and logic. Sometimes too much. There's got to be an explanation. There can't be an animal in there. But I saw something.

question: What was it?
answer: I don't know. Mr. Pendergast. Do me a favor. Get me a DNA readout on that claw.

question: Bailey? Doyle here. I'm still waiting outside the exhibit. Where the hell is McNitt?
answer: Should be there any minute. They came out a side door a while ago. Said the exhibit's clear. McNitt's headed back to spell you.

question: I'm on double over-time, man.
answer: I know. You can go home if you want to. I'll come relieve you myself.

question: McNitt here. I'm outside the exhibit. All's quiet. But I don't see Doyle.
answer: He called a minute ago looking for you. He starts vacation tomorrow and he wanted out. I said you were on the way. He could split.

question: Well he's gone.
answer: Any sign of a green-eyed monster?

question: I appreciate that.
answer: If the party goes forward, and that's a big if... I've arranged for a large police presence.

question: Do they have to wear uniforms?
answer: Yes.

question: I don't want to scare people.
answer: I understand. But Mr. Cuthbert, we've got bigger problems. Depending on what we find today, we may have to shut you down.

question: My kind of art. My favorite is the two camels.
answer: Did you ever wonder where we get all our skeletons? This is the laboratory where animal carcasses are reduced to bones. What's cooking today, Don?

question: Man, that's ripe.
answer: Dermestid beetles. The second method of preparing a skeleton, used in Natural History Museums world wide. Bugs are clean and highly efficient. They'll polish that fox off in no time. Thanks Don. We're in a hurry. Some other time. This should be it. Can you read the number?

question: Holy shit.
answer: Something tried to get into this room!

question: This on top of the scratches... isn't it proof!
answer: I think the scratches were put there to scare us. Perhaps even lead us to this note. You said John Whittlesley made a study of your blueprints of the museum.

question: Yes.
answer: Are there any hidden rooms or staircases? Places where someone could hide?

question: Not really. Just the sub-basement.
answer: Where is that?

question: I don't know. It was walled over. No one's been down there in years.
answer: You said you had plans of the museum. Could we see them, please?

question: This huge police presence tonight isn't necessary, Lieutenant. You'll just scare people off. I can handle the security behind scenes with this system. It's state of the art.
answer: The cops are non-negotiable, Ippolito. Why don't you just tell me how this space station works.

question: It's fool proof, basically. I designed this whole thing myself. Every valuable object in the Museum carries a small electronic chip. If anything's moved so much as an inch, we get an alarm pinpointing the exact location of the attempted theft.
answer: That's great if you're stopping a burglar. Not our goal here. Are there motion detectors?

question: In every exhibition room. The museum's divided into five cells. The reception and exhibit are in cell five. We could arm the motion detectors in cells one to four, then seal the perimeter with our fire doors.
answer: That would leave one exit for hundreds of people. You'd be violating every fire regulation on the books. We'll guard the perimeter with my men and engage the motion detectors in the other cells. One more question. I see a big hole. If this entire thing is run by computer, what happens if the power fails?

question: I can't help thinking there's something that Pendergast overlooked. If the scratches were made by whatever killed Beauregard, it wants something that's in here.
answer: A blow dart. Seed pods. A plant press. Pretty unimpressive stuff.

question: Let me see the plant press.
answer: What is it?

question: I'm not sure. As you know, the Kothoga lived outside civilization on the tepui for thousands of years. Species flourished in isolation when man and pollution rendered them extinct. This could be one of the last remaining samples of an unknown plant.
answer: Whatever it is, it must be common on the tepui. John used it as packing material.

question: Hard to read in this light. The ink is so faded.
answer: The dogs have lost the scent, Mr. Pendergast. Maybe we should head back.

question: Not yet. Let's try the fork to the left.
answer: They've got something.

question: Keep the light up. I can't see. Shut them up!
answer: Heel Argo! Hobbes! Heel! They're going crazy! I need help! He's loose! Argo!

question: Stop!
answer: Holy mother, what is that?

question: Argo! Come!
answer: Quiet!

question: No! Hobbes!
answer: Forget the dogs. You two, get back here. Don't point that gun at me.

question: Argo! Hobbes!
answer: Get back! Now!

question: You shot my dog! My dog...
answer: He was coming right at me...

question: I'm not going anywhere! Not without my dog! Hobbes!
answer: Get back!

question: I'm ordering you! Cover me!
answer: Look. It's Hobbes! He's all right.

question: Come on. Let's get back to the others. We can't leave them alone.
answer: It's alright. I can tell by the way the dog's acting that whatever was out there is gone. What is this place?

question: Not on the map. Looks like it connects with the city sewer. We're coming back! Identify yourself! Who's there?
answer: Oh... my... God!

question: I'm telling you, something's wrong. I still haven't heard from Pendergast. I think you should call it off.
answer: It's too late now. Guests are arriving. The Mayor's car is pulling up.

question: I'll go down and speak to him.
answer: You haven't got the authority. Only Pendergast can pull the plug.

question: Pendergast may be in trouble. Don't you understand? He still hasn't come back. It's been over three hours --
answer: He'll be back. Relax. We're in good shape. Your security is air tight. There've been no more incidents, nothing suspicious. There's no reason to call off the opening now.

question: It's reptilian.
answer: Like the claw.

question: Let's not jump to conclusions. This egg could belong to any number of reptiles, Dr. Frock.
answer: Come on, Margo. We're on the verge of something huge. Let's consider the possibility, just the three of us, alone in this room. What if John was right. I mean, what if? And he sent back an egg of his monster in the crates. When it got to the museum, it hatched.

question: But a virus normally codes for other viruses. This one's making human and animal proteins. Listen to this. "Glycotetraglycine collagenoid. Weinstein's tropic hormone. 4- monoxytocin supressin hormone."
answer: These plant fibers are loaded with hormones!

question: What kind of hormones?
answer: 4-monoxytocin is... "A hormone secreted by the human hypothalamus gland."

question: This is it. This is what he, or it... is after! The plant has high concentrations of the same hormones found in minute quantities in the human brain!
answer: So what?

question: Pendergast told me the killer extracts and eats the hypothalamus and thalamus of the victim's brains!
answer: Eats them?

question: All right, assuming the program is accurate, this is a description of the animal with that claw. "Species unidentified. Genus
answer: Quadrupedal! The other name for Mbwun. "He Who Walks on All Fours."

question: "Nocturnal. External hair and bony plates. Locomotor speed 60-70 kilometers. Reduced optic chiasm"... poor eyesight. "External mucoid nasal glands,"... very keen scent... "Morphological characteristics
answer: So the claw came from a huge creature with a preternatural sense of smell and poor eyesight that hunts at night.

question: With the intelligence of a human being, the speed of a greyhound, and the strength of a grizzly bear.
answer: Margo, what you've just described is a killing machine.

question: And it's hungry. It's been two days since it's eaten. There are five hundred people arriving right now. The animal hunts at night and it has a keen sense of smell! All those people in one enclosed space...
answer: It's like ringing the dinner bell.

question: Lieutenant! It's me.
answer: What is it?

question: Dr. Green has to see you!
answer: Got my hands full here.

question: It's important. Please. You have to come! Pendergast, too. She's found out something.
answer: McNitt? D'Agosta here.

question: McNitt? D'Agosta here.
answer: Yeah Lieutenant? I'm here.

question: I'm heading to the Evolutionary Bio labs. Any sign of Pendergast?
answer: Not yet. Hold on Lieutenant. What was that? Lieutenant? There's something wrong in the computer room.

question: Here we have a very rare sacrificial table from Mesoamerica. The priests would kill the victim on this slab, cut out the heart and eat it while it was still beating.
answer: I could use one of these things in City Hall.

question: Kid will love it. They're our target audience. Nothing here is as violent as what they see on T.V.
answer: I don't know. That could be a little over the top. It's not even scientific. Mummies don't bleed.

question: There's a dead body in the exhibit! People are panicking, trampling each other trying to get out. What the hell is going on?!
answer: The whole system is shutting down! We have to get out quickly before the fire doors fall!

question: What doors?
answer: I told you! They seal off all the cells. They were designed to fall automatically in a system failure --

question: What's going on?
answer: Some kind of power failure. Maybe it's the storm. Do you have a flashlight?

question: I think so.
answer: Greg's been gone over a half hour. We'd better get out of here. Get the crate.

question: Dr. Frock. Did you hear that?
answer: Don't stop now.

question: What's that?
answer: It's one of the fire doors. Good Lord, Margo. We're trapped!

question: I know where we are now. We're getting out, Jonathan. This should be another door.
answer: Hallelujah, Pendergast. Where the hell are we now? Jesus, what is this?

question: Another storage room. Something's happened. The power's out. All right. I know where we are. This is the osteo prep lab. I was in here earlier. We're safe now.
answer: Oh no. I smell it.

question: Dr. Frock! Quick! Pendergast? Are you all right?
answer: No. I think I'm hallucinating.

question: You're not. Where is it?
answer: Gone.

question: Wounded?
answer: No. A chromium alloy tipped .45 caliber bullet bounced off that thing's skull like a spit ball. I think it was bothered by my light.

question: Is there a doctor? Check this woman and see if anyone else needs you.
answer: Lieutenant D'Agosta! Don't shoot.

question: Where's Pendergast?
answer: Five flights down. We were lost in the sub-basement. Something's down there. It killed our two deputies. When I left Pendergast it was coming back. He sent me for help. We have to hurry.

question: All right. You're elected. Bailey, get all the guns and flashlights, give the mayor your walkie talkie so we can keep in touch. Cuthbert, keep everyone together and make sure they stay quiet.
answer: I was in the Marines. Give me a gun. I'd go with you, too, but I've got my daughter.

question: What's your name?
answer: Frank.

question: On three. One, two... three. Jonathan! Get everyone behind me!
answer: It went out the door to the rotunda!

question: Get everyone into the stairwell!
answer: Sweet Jesus!

question: Get his gun and his walkie talkie, Jonathan. Move.
answer: My office is on the third floor! There's a walk-in safe and a portable phone! We can lock ourselves in the safe and call for help!

question: Panic attack. D'Agosta, put on the Mayor.
answer: Mayor Jordan here.

question: This is Ippolito, head of museum security. Relieve D'Agosta and take command.
answer: Don't tell me what to do you chicken shit bastard. I saw you cut and run! Lieutenant D'Agosta stayed with us. He is in charge. There is a monster. I saw it. Cut through those doors and get us out of here, now!

question: Solid oak. Two inches thick. Tell me they'll hold. I got it after I was mugged in the subway last spring.
answer: Where's the walk-in safe?

question: Behind you.
answer: What's the combination?

question: I'll do it. Just let me find my portable phone.
answer: Forget it!

question: Calm down. I found it! Battery's dead. Shit.
answer: Let's go!

question: That thing won't come after us, right? It's going for bigger game. The group blundering around in the basement. Poor fools.
answer: Hurry up!

question: Just a minute. I'm shaking! Take the gun. Oh God! I dropped my rabbit's foot!
answer: For Chrissake, I'll do it. What's the combination?!

question: To the left twice then five no... sorry... I think it's fifteen... it's been a while...
answer: Oh Jesus... Fifteen... what's next?

question: Hide quickly!
answer: What are you going to do?

question: Buy them some time. Hey you big tub of lard! Over here! Come on, you smelly pile of refuse. Come get me. I dare you!
answer: What is it doing?

question: It's scared of me. Drop the fibers! What happened?
answer: Its eyesight is worse than I thought. It couldn't see us. And it couldn't smell us through the glass.

question: It didn't want the fibers. What does that mean?
answer: I think... it means it's full.

question: Then it won't go after the others?
answer: No. It's still hunting, but not for the hormones.

question: For what?
answer: I think... for the pleasure of the kill.

question: No, Lieutenant. He's not a good enough shot. I'll do it if you take care of my daughter.
answer: Damn. It's getting deep. See anything?

question: You'll be the first to know.
answer: Pendergast? I made the right hand fork. We're already in about three feet of water. Where should we go? Hello!

question: Sweet Jesus, help!
answer: Frank! Are you all right!

question: Vince? Can you hear me? Vince!
answer: We have to try and draw it off!

question: How?
answer: The answer's right in front of us. That's a ptarmigan, feigning a broken wing. The bird pretends to be injured to draw the fox away from its nest!

question: It's deceptively simple. Like a Bruckner Symphony or a Matisse.
answer: Help! Please someone! Help!

question: At least we'll be dry.
answer: I believe in you a hundred percent, Vince, but that's the second time we've been at that intersection.

question: Not so loud.
answer: What's that?

question: All right everybody, hold up! We don't know what's in there. Let me go first. What does it say?
answer: Dr. John Whittlesley.

question: What's that doing here?
answer: I don't know. I thought Dr. Whittlesley died in South America.

question: We're not going to make the storage room!
answer: Listen to me, Pendergast. Mbwun's DNA is part homo sapien. In primates, the eye is a direct path to the brain! If you get a clean shot, there's only one place you can kill it. Shoot it in the eye!

question: Please, no! Don't hurt Margo!
answer: My God. You understand. Please let me go. We won't hurt you.

question: Run!
answer: John's necklace! You killed him! Oh Jesus. John? No. It's not possible! John? If it is you... I can help. No! Don't kill him! Pendergast, you were right. It's John!

question: What?
answer: That thing is John Whittlesley. I should have seen it before! The fibers are infected with a virus. You eat them, and the virus alters your DNA! He became addicted to them in South America, followed the plants back to the states. He probably entered the country as a man. It would have taken several months for the change to take place. That's how he got from the boat to the museum!

question: I don't believe it.
answer: You have to! Listen! All viruses pass on their own DNA. Instruct the cells of the host to make more viruses! This one was different. It inserted a whole array of genes into John. Reptile genes, sixty five million years old. Those genes remade him! It's not his fault!

question: Just like John. He won't listen.
answer: I have to shoot.

question: Do it, quickly. Please. Aim for the eye.
answer: He has to look here or I won't get a clear shot. Call him, Margo.

question: I can't!
answer: You have to. Do it now!

question: No time for fishing anymore?
answer: Got to finish this thesis sometime.

question: How about lunch?
answer: Not today. Besides, I think the director of the museum is expecting you.
